results.justification: The document explicitly states the research aims to re-examine theoretical models of affect dynamics using data from a classroom study. It details the use of epistemic network analysis (ENA) and BROMP-based detectors.
Sections 3.2 and 3.3 provide a detailed, step-by-step description of the data collection (affective state labeling with BROMP observations) and analysis (ENA, ONA) procedures.
The document does not mention the public availability of the raw or processed datasets.
There is no justification provided for why the data cannot be shared.
While the document describes the data collected (demographic questionnaire, pre/post-tests, affective states), it does not provide a comprehensive data dictionary or codebook.

Data collection methods are described, including the use of pre-surveys (demographic, science content, situational interest, self-efficacy), post-surveys, and BROMP observations during gameplay (Section 3.1 and 3.2).
The document does not mention the availability of the analysis code in an open repository.
There is no justification provided for why the code cannot be shared.
The document does not mention the availability of code used for data preparation or preprocessing.
Statistical tests (ONA, Mann-Whitney U test with Benjamini-Hochberg correction) and models (epistemic network analysis) are described.
Tables 2, 3, 4, and 5 present rates, line weights, and differences, providing quantitative results. Statistical significance is also addressed.
The document provides subjective context and interpretation of the results, particularly in the discussion of the SDVET model and the meaning of observed affective transitions.
While the document describes the process of using BROMP detectors, it does not detail the data coding or analysis process beyond the statistical methods applied.
Results are presented in tables and figures, with clear descriptions of the observed patterns and trends (e.g., changes in affective states over time, differences based on self-efficacy).
The document discusses limitations, such as the inability of BROMP detectors to differentiate between types of frustration and the need for further research to explore these nuances (Section 5.3).
The document does not contain a link to a preregistration.
